block.p: Mozart and Swing At Washington Square

The 42nd season of the Washington Square Music Festival is presenting free Tuesday night concerts in the park under Henry Schuman, the musical director. In this Tuesday's concert, ''Mozart Masterpieces,'' Mr. Schuman will conduct the Festival Orchestra.
Mozart and Swing At Washington Square

The 42nd season of the Washington Square Music Festival is presenting free Tuesday night concerts in the park under Henry Schuman, the musical director. In this Tuesday's concert, ''Mozart Masterpieces,'' Mr. Schuman will conduct the Festival Orchestra.
Works will include Mozart's Clarinet Concerto, with Steven Hartman as soloist, and the Symphony No. 40 in G minor.

On July 25, the Felix Swing Band will perform the music of Thomas Wright, Fats Waller and others. The big band swing group features Sol Yaged on the clarinet, Felix Endico on piano, and Clarence Bean on drums.

Washington Square Music Festival; ''Mozart Masterpieces'': Tuesday 8 p.m., rain space: New York University's Frederick Loewe Theater, 35 West Fourth Street; Felix Swing Band, July 25, 8 p.m., rain space: Washington Square United Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street; both events free; (212) 431-1088.
UPPER EAST SIDE Where It's Cool To Be in School in July
The ''Jazz in July'' series at the 92nd Street Y turns 16 years old this summer, with six shows over two weeks led by Dick Hyman, the jazz pianist, historian, composer and arranger.

Kickoff night is Tuesday with ''Cool School,'' a program recalling the cool jazz sounds of the 1950's and 1960's, epitomized by artists like Stan Getz and Lee Konitz. Wednesday night's performance ranges from contemporary to swing and traditional to classical jazz piano with ''Dick and Derek's Annual Piano Party,'' with Mr. Hyman and Derek Smith. Thursday it's ''Triple Threat,'' three trios with three different styles, led by Bucky Pizzarelli, Mr. Hyman and Kenny Davern, a clarinetist (left), rehearsing with Joe Wilder (right), on trumpet. The series continues through July 27.
''Jazz in July;'' Tuesday through July 27; 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue at 92d Street; $35; $30 each for six or more tickets; (212) 996-1100.
QUEENS Art in Various Guises At the Library
The central library and 62 neighborhood branches of the Queens Borough Public Library provide a place for local artists to exhibit their work.
Throughout the summer, the work of 11 Queens artists will be on view in various branches in the 17th annual Individual Artist Showcase.
The work of Paul Farinacci can be seen through tomorrow at the Court Square Branch.

Coming shows include mixed media art by Chan Hee Hong from July 31 through Aug. 21 at the Langston Hughes Community Library and Cultural Center and the photography of Alexander Berens from Aug. 7 through Aug. 28 in Rego Park.
The paintings of Cecil Chong, including ''Nocturnal Flower,'' the oil shown below, will close out the season at the Jackson Heights Branch from Sept. 4 through Sept. 25.
Individual Artist Showcase; at various branches of the Queens Borough Public Library; free; for full schedule and locations, (718) 990-8643.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

NEWCOMER DRAMAS -- The family pig is a main topic in ''Pernil,'' and the question of when a joke is not a joke is explored in ''Valet Parking''; these two films will be shown in the ''American Dreams'' series of the Immigrants' Theater Project and the Lower East Side Tenement Museum; Thursday 8 p.m.; Tenement Theater, 97 Orchard Street between Broome and Delancey Streets; $5; information: (718) 237-4545, reservations: (212) 431-0223 ext. 440.

THE WALK OF LIFE -- The Big Onion walking tour of SoHo and NoLIta stops at sites including Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, the ''little'' Singer Building and places associated with Emma Goldman and with Keith Haring; Saturday 1 p.m.; meet at the southeast corner of Spring and Lafayette Streets; $12; students and people over 65, $10; (212) 439-1090.

HOPE FOR POETS -- A Poetry in the Garden event this afternoon will have an open microphone, coffee and performances in a summer series presented by Hope Community; 2 to 5 p.m.; Modesto Flores Garden, Lexington Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets; free; (212) 860-8821.
ANDREA DELBANCO
